awd_titl_txt: GEM: Global versus Local Control of Solar Wind-Magnetospheric Coupling
awd_abstract_narration:
Magnetic reconnection is basically the breaking and reconfiguring of magnetic field lines so that the Earth's and interplanetary magnetic field lines (IMF) become interconnected for a time. In this process, magnetic energy is converted into heat and kinetic energy of charged particles and drives the circulation of plasmas and electromagnetic energy through the magnetosphere. A debate is ongoing in the space physics community about whether the integrated dayside magnetic reconnection rate is controlled by local plasma conditions at the reconnection site (called local-control) or whether the reconnection rate is controlled by the solar wind electric field  (called global-control). The primary goal of the work is to use global MHD simulations to address this controversy. Knowledge of what controls the rate of dayside magnetic reconnection is critical to understanding how the geospace system works and, ultimately, improving space weather prediction of value to a technology-dependent society. 
 
Global magnetospheric simulations with selected changes to the local plasma parameters in the reconnection region (uniform resistivity, localized resistivity, or the Hall term) will be performed with identical solar wind conditions for a range of orientations of the IMF to determine whether the change in local reconnection physics alters the global magnetospheric response.  A secondary goal is to determine how well 2D local reconnection models describe magnetic reconnection. Data-model comparisons will be conducted using satellite data to test the applicability of the modeling results to Earth's magnetosphere.

por.por_cntn:
There has been a long-standing debate in the attempt to understand how Earth?s protective magnetic field (the magnetosphere) responds to bombardment by the superheated plasma (ionized gas) known as the solar wind. The solar wind carries with it a magnetic field, and the solar wind plasma and magnetic field travel out through interplanetary space, where it impinges on Earth's magnetic field. There, a process called magnetic reconnection occurs. During reconnection, magnetic field lines effectively break and cross-connect. When this fundamental phenomenon occurs on the "dayside" of the edge of the magnetosphere (called the magnetopause), it sets in motion a complicated set of phenomena that drive activity in Earth's magnetosphere, which loads magnetic energy on the "nightside" of the magnetosphere that eventually gets eruptively released and drives the auroral light display and space weather. This is called the Dungey cycle, and it is an age-old problem to be able to predict how rapidly the Dungey cycle takes place solely from a knowledge of the plasma and magnetic field conditions in the solar wind.


When Dungey discovered the cycle that now bears his name, he realized that the rate at which magnetic reconnection occurs at the dayside magnetopause determines how rapidly the cycle occurs. Thus, developing a predictive understanding of the Dungey cycle requires an understanding of the rate reconnection at the dayside. In 1983, Axford conjectured that the rate at which dayside magnetic reconnection occurs is determined wholly by the boundary conditions, i.e., the plasma and magnetic field conditions in the solar wind, and presumably also within Earth's magnetosphere - in other words, he posited the reconnection process self adjusts to proceed at whatever rate it has to to process the material and fields coming in. This was the dominant idea for many years and led to the development of quantitative predictions. However, satellite and ground based observations revealed that the Axford conjecture does an adequate job of explaining the observed metrics used to quantify the Dungey cycle, and other quantities were developed that agreed with the data even better than Axford's prediction. In 2008, Borovsky surprised the community by suggesting the Axford conjecture was incorrect, and the rate of reconnection is set by local physics rather than the global-scale boundary conditions. This spurred a flurry of research to try to determine which scenario between global and local - if either extreme - is valid.


Previous studies to address this question with numerical simulations only addressed the question tangentially, so this project is to directly test the Axford conjecture with numerical simulations. The overarching goals of this project are to: (1) quantitatively assess how changing local reconnection physics affects the local and global magnetospheric response, if at all, and (2) determine whether two-dimensional local reconnection models appropriately describe magnetospheric reconnection.


To carry out these goals, we performed global magnetospheric simulations with different local reconnection physics as quantified by the resistivity that describes how rapidly collisions between the protons and electrons making up the plasma occur, while keeping identical solar wind conditions.  We first measured the local properties of dayside reconnection quantitatively to determine if local changes to the reconnection physics alter the local magnetospheric response. Then, in the same simulations, we determined whether the change in local reconnection physics alters the global magnetospheric response. Finally, we use satellite observations from the Magnetospheric Multiscale (MMS) mission to determine if local two-dimensional reconnection models are consistent with observations.

We found that changing the local physics does have an impact on the local and global rate of reconnection - changing the collisionality in a series of simulations resulted in a 20 percent change in the global reconnection rate. The results are qualitatively consistent with a "modified Axford conjecture" proffered by Lopez - that changes to the local reconnection process can alter the local quantities at the reconnection site, which if strong enough can deflect the solar wind plasma in a different way and therefore cause changes to the global reconnection rate. We found the local reconnection rate is reasonably described by an existing model of the local rate of reconnection at the dayside magnetopause. MMS observations agreed that the locally measured reconnection rate is comparable to predictions. We expect these results will influence further efforts to finally quantify the rate of solar wind-magnetospheric coupling, which is an important intellectual merit of the study and should improve future models of space weather prediction.


For broader impacts of this project, the PI continued his successful outreach partnership with "Spark! Imagination and Science Center" in Morgantown, participating in multiple outreach events, maintaining a Space Weather exhibit we created at the museum, and serving as the science adviser for the development of at-home science activities for children to do during the lockdown during the COVID-19 pandemic.
